verses.text: Now Boaz went up to the gate and sat down there. And behold, the redeemer of whom Boaz had spoken passed by. So Boaz said, “Turn aside, friend; sit down here.” So he turned aside and sat down.
verses.comment: The term 'redeemer' refers to the kinsman-redeemer (Hebrew: go'el); the gate was the city’s place for legal business.

verses.text: And Boaz took ten men of the elders of the city and said, “Sit down here.” So they sat down.
verses.comment: Ten elders constituted a valid legal assembly in ancient Israel.

verses.text: Then he said to the redeemer, “Naomi, who has come back from the country of Moab, is selling the piece of land that belonged to our brother Elimelech.
verses.comment: ‘Brother’ is used here in the broader sense of kinsman or close relative.

verses.text: So I thought I should inform you, saying, ‘Buy it in the presence of those sitting here and in the presence of the elders of my people. If you will redeem it, redeem it; but if you will not, tell me, so that I may know. For there is no one besides you to redeem it, and I come after you.’” And he said, “I will redeem it.”
verses.comment: Boaz presents the offer to the nearer kinsman first, per Israelite custom.

verses.text: Then Boaz said, “On the day you buy the field from the hand of Naomi, you also acquire Ruth the Moabitess, the wife of the dead, to raise up the name of the dead in his inheritance.”
verses.comment: The duty includes marrying Ruth to provide an heir for Elimelech’s family.

verses.text: Then the redeemer said, “I cannot redeem it for myself, lest I impair my own inheritance. Take my right of redemption yourself, for I cannot redeem it.”
verses.comment: Redeemer declines due to risk to his own estate.

verses.text: Now this was the custom in former times in Israel concerning redeeming and exchanging: to confirm any transaction, one man took off his sandal and gave it to the other, and this was the manner of attestation in Israel.
verses.comment: Removing the sandal symbolized transfer of rights.

verses.text: So when the redeemer said to Boaz, “Buy it for yourself,” he took off his sandal.
verses.comment: Short summary repeating the transfer ritual.

verses.text: Then Boaz said to the elders and all the people, “You are witnesses this day that I have bought from the hand of Naomi all that belonged to Elimelech and all that belonged to Chilion and Mahlon.
verses.comment: Boaz makes a legal declaration before the witnesses.

verses.text: Moreover, Ruth the Moabitess, the widow of Mahlon, I have acquired to be my wife, to raise up the name of the dead on his inheritance, so that the name of the dead will not be cut off from among his brothers and from the gate of his native place. You are witnesses this day.”
verses.comment: Boaz fulfills the ‘levirate’ duty to preserve family name and property.

verses.text: And all the people who were at the gate, and the elders, said, “We are witnesses. May the LORD make the woman who is coming into your house like Rachel and Leah, who together built up the house of Israel. May you act worthily in Ephrathah and be renowned in Bethlehem.
verses.comment: Blessing reflects desire for Ruth to be as fruitful as Israel’s founding mothers.

verses.text: And may your house be like the house of Perez, whom Tamar bore to Judah, because of the offspring that the LORD will give you by this young woman.”
verses.comment: Reference to Perez and Tamar links Ruth’s story to ancestry of King David.

verses.text: So Boaz took Ruth, and she became his wife. And he went in to her, and the LORD gave her conception, and she bore a son.
verses.comment: Simple expression of marriage, intimacy, and birth as in Hebrew narrative.

verses.text: Then the women said to Naomi, “Blessed be the LORD, who has not left you this day without a redeemer, and may his name be renowned in Israel!
verses.comment: The redeemer here refers to the new child, the heir.

verses.text: He shall be to you a restorer of life and a nourisher of your old age; for your daughter-in-law, who loves you, who is better to you than seven sons, has given birth to him.”
verses.comment: ‘Seven sons’ was a Hebrew idiom for the ideal family legacy.

verses.text: Then Naomi took the child and laid him on her lap and became his nurse.
verses.comment: Naomi acting as ‘nurse’ here means caring, not literal wet-nursing.

verses.text: And the women of the neighborhood gave him a name, saying, “A son has been born to Naomi.” They named him Obed. He was the father of Jesse, the father of David.
verses.comment: Obed means ‘servant’; the genealogy links Ruth to King David.

verses.text: Now these are the generations of Perez: Perez fathered Hezron,
verses.comment: ‘Generations’ is Hebrew ‘toledot’—typical start to genealogies.

verses.text: Hezron fathered Ram, Ram fathered Amminadab,
verses.comment: Stays with the original names and order.

verses.text: Amminadab fathered Nahshon, Nahshon fathered Salmon,
verses.comment: Genealogical record aligns with other Old Testament lists.

verses.text: Salmon fathered Boaz, Boaz fathered Obed,
verses.comment: As in the genealogy of Jesus in Matthew.

verses.text: Obed fathered Jesse, and Jesse fathered David.
verses.comment: Closes with David, showing Ruth’s significance in Israel’s royal lineage.
